results.title: Celebrations: New Year
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
Narrated by Eileen Darley, this program aimed at younger children looks at the celebrations surrounding New Year. It explores why people gather on December 31st and outlines characteristics of the event such as the countdown, singing Auld Lang Syne, and making resolutions. As a point of comparison the program then looks at how people in the Jewish tradition celebrate new year, and the celebrations surrounding Chinese New Year, revealing that food plays a major role in both. Suitable for children 4-8.

results.title: Celebrations: new baby
results.creator_credit: Caroline Jones and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
A short program aimed at children aged 6-8 outlining the ways people celebrate the addition of a new baby into their lives. Sharing the thoughts of a young boy who meets his new sister for the first time, and then later as they bring the baby home. The way people of different cultures celebrate the birth of a baby are also show, including a Catholic christening and a Vietnamese feast. Each family celebrates the birth in a different way, but all share the same purpose: to welcome a baby into their lives.

results.title: Celebrations: christmas
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
Narrated by Eileen Darley, this program aimed at young children looks at the celebrations surrounding Christmas. It follows the signs and symbols that signify Christmas is near, such as shopping, store and street decorations, advent calendars, parades, sending cards, making your own gifts, decorating trees, the importance of being with people you love, and being charitable to those in need. The program also looks at the origins of Christmas trees and cards, and the story of the first Christmas. Delicious traditional Christmas fare from Italy and Germany are also shown. Suitable for children 4-8.

results.title: Celebrations: birthdays
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
A short program aimed at children aged 4-8 discussing the different aspects of preparing for and celebrating a birthday, comparing a traditional birthday party for an Australian child to a German and an Asian child. Also shows how people of all ages celebrate birthdays, and explains just what a birthday is.

results.title: Celebrations: achievement
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
A short program aimed at children aged 4-8 narrated by Carolyn Jones showing the different ways that people celebrate achieving certain goals. Following a group of year 7 students to their graduation from school, comparing their preparation and celebration to a group of Police Force cadets preparing to graduate from the Academy. Also discussed is the importance of acknowledging all achievements, no matter how small they may seem.

results.title: Celebrations of people and place : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: The East Reservoir Neighbourhood Renewal was set up in 2006 when the area was identified as being in need and enabling residents to help create a community action plan. Part of this process has been to invite seven members of the community to participate in a Digital Storytelling workshop to tell very personal stories the reflect life in the suburb.

results.title: Celebrations
results.brief_description: Features two films recounting the history and development of the SEC. “Fifty Years of Service” focuses on the history of electricity in Victoria from the late 1800’s to the development of the SEC in 1919. Highlights the achievements of Sir John Monash, the first General Manager and Chairman of the SEC. Looks at the development of power plants at Yallourn, Morwell, Hazelwood and Kiewa. Examples of the impact of electricity on domestic life at the time is shown with new appliances such as hair dryers and vacuum cleaners entering the home. (33 min) “Generations of Power” is another historical retrospective this time with comments from several SEC staff members from between the 1940’s to 1990’s. Includes a decade by decade look at the impact of electricity on Victorian Society. (23 min)

results.title: Celebrations
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
Centred around various festivals, particularly the Spring festival or Chinese New Year, this program looks at the lion dance, the use of firecrackers weddings, birthdays and the Chinese national day. Vocabulary learnt is centred around time, with examples being, “How long?”, “time off”, “often”, “How many?”. Professor Colin Mackerras attends a wedding and explains how a wedding is celebrated, and some of the traditions associated with birthdays. The calligraphy section shows various characters for different festivals. There are dramatised sequences which show a family celebrating the Spring festival, and a birthday, and we also witness a performance of “Waltzing Matilda” in Chinese.

results.title: Celebrations
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: A documentary film presenting six different and authentic celebrations involving people in the multicultural community of Melbourne. Depicts an Aboriginal dance showing body decoration preparation, an Indonesian Muslim wedding celebration, an Australian child’s birthday party, a Greek nameday party, Christmas festivities and a Northern Italian Christmas celebration. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.
